revision.comment: Jesswade88 moved page [[Yajaira Sierra Sastre]] to [[Yajaira Sierra-Sastre]]: missed hyphen
revision.text:
{{Infobox person | name = Yajaira Sierra Sastre | image = | imagesize = 150px | caption = Dr. Yajaira Sierra Sastre | birth_date = 1977 | birth_place = [[Guayama, Puerto Rico|Guayama]], [[Puerto Rico]] | death_date = | nationality = [[Puerto Rican citizenship|Puerto Rican]] | occupation = [[Nanotechnology]] scientist and educator | salary = | networth = | spouse = | children = | signature = | website = | footnotes = }}
Dr. '''Yajaira Sierra-Sastre'''<ref group=note>{{Spanish name|'''Sierra'''|'''Sastre'''|plain=yes}}</ref> (born 1977) is a [[Puerto Rican people|Puerto Rican]] [[nanotechnology]] scientist, educator, mentor and aspiring [[astronaut]]. She is part of a six-person crew, and the only [[Hispanic]], selected to participate in a four-month-long, Mars analog mission funded by NASA.<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=http://www.sciencemag.org/careers/2016/10/making-money-eye-sky|title=Making money, with an eye to the sky|last=Levine|first=Alaina|date=October 10, 2016|work=Science Magazine|access-date=}}</ref> Sierra-Sastre aspires to become the first [[Puerto Rican people|Puerto Rican]] woman to travel to [[outer space]].<!-- Note: All the references in regard to the introduction can be found within the artile -->
==Early years== Sierra-Sastre was born in [[Guayama, Puerto Rico]],<ref name="manoa.hawaii.edu">[http://manoa.hawaii.edu/hi-seas/CrewBios.pdf ''HI-SEAS: Hawaii Space Exploration Analog and Simulation. HI-SEAS, What is HI-SEAS: Crew Bios.''] University of Hawaii at Manoa. 26 June 2012. Retrieved 27 July 2012.</ref> and raised in the town of [[Arroyo, Puerto Rico|Arroyo]] where she received her secondary education. Throughout her childhood, she dreamed of becoming an astronaut. After graduating from Carmen Bozello de Huyke High School, she attended the [[University of Puerto Rico at Mayagüez|Mayagüez Campus of the University of Puerto Rico]] where she earned a [[Bachelor of Science]] degree in [[Chemistry]].<ref name="manoa.hawaii.edu"/> After teaching to middle and high school students for a year and a half, Sierra-Sastre participated as a post-baccalaureate in an internship at Stanford University, where she was first introduced to nanotechnology research.<ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=https://www.hercampus.com/school/uprm/yajaira-sierra-sastre-life-mars|title=Yajaira Sierra Sastre: Life on Mars?|work=Her Campus|access-date=2018-11-17|language=en}}</ref> During that time, she was trained in the self-assembly of mono-molecular films. Upon returning to [[Puerto Rico]], she enrolled in graduate Environmental Health courses at the School of Public Health at the University of Puerto Rico Medical Science Campus and graduate Chemistry courses at the [[University of Puerto Rico at Río Piedras]]. Sierra-Sastre then attended [[Cornell University]], where she earned a [[Ph.D.]] in 2009 in [[Materials Chemistry|materials chemistry]] and [[nanotechnology]] and specialized in the nanofabrication of semi-conductor nanowires.<ref name="HSN">[http://www.elnuevodia.com/laborinquenamaspequena-1222612.html "La Borinqueña’ más pequeña"; El Nuevo Dia]</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hispanicallyspeakingnews.com/notitas-de-noticias/details/yajaira-sierra-one-step-closer-to-becoming-first-puerto-rican-woman-in-spac/17115/ |title=Yajaira Sierra One Step Closer to Becoming First Puerto Rican Woman in Space |publisher=Hispanicallyspeakingnews.com |date= |accessdate=2013-09-20}}</ref><ref name=":1" /> As part of her doctoral studies, Sierra-Sastre researched at [[Los Alamos National Laboratory]].<ref name="manoa.hawaii.edu" />
==NASA's Mars simulation project== NASA realized that, in long duration missions, astronauts do not eat enough. They experience "menu fatigue" and their overall food intake declines, which puts them at risk of nutritional deficiency, loss of bone and muscle mass, and [[lethargy]]. The NASA Human Research Program is funding a project called "[[HI-SEAS]]," an [[acronym]] for “Hawaii Space Exploration Analog and Simulation,” to determine the best way to keep astronauts well nourished during multiple-year missions to [[Mars]] or the moon.<ref name="HSN"/><ref name="MCN">{{cite web|url=http://www.bigislandvideonews.com/2012/07/10/video-six-person-crew-selected-for-nasa-mars-food-mission/ |title=VIDEO: NASA Mars food mission crew named |publisher=Bigislandvideonews.com |date=2012-07-10 |accessdate=2013-09-20}}</ref>
A planetary module was built on the Hawaiian island of [[Mauna Loa]], which simulates the living conditions for astronauts at a future base on Mars. It is believed that the saddle area side of the island resembles a Martian environment.<ref name="HSN"/><ref name="MCN"/> {{external media | align = left | video1 = You may watch and listen to Dr. Yajaira Sierra Sastre during an interview [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QIP0yL4C6Jo '''here'''] }}
After receiving more than 700 applications for positions as crew members of the simulated Mars mission, NASA and researchers from Cornell University and the University of Hawaii at Mānoa chose six astronaut-like individuals. Sierra-Sastre was part of the selected crew with qualifications similar to those required by NASA for their astronaut applicants. The other five are Dr. Oleg Abramov, Simon Engler, Kate Greene, Sian Proctor and [[Angelo Vermeulen]]. Three additional individuals will make up the reserve crew.<ref name="HSN"/><ref name="MCN"/>
Prior to the four-month mission, which began on March 2013, the crew participated in a two-week training session. Once the mission began the crew was not to be allowed to have any communication with the outside world, except for limited [[e-mail]]. If they step outside the module they will have to wear simulated space suits. During the mission they will test new forms of food and food preparation strategies for [[Outer space|deep-space]] travel.<ref name="HSN"/><ref name="MCN"/>
Sierra-Sastre and her colleagues emerged from the space habitat on August 13, ending the four-month simulated mission. According to Sierra-Sastre and the scientists involved in the mission, the food ingredients that will be essential for future space missions on Mars or the moon will include spices, herbs and hot sauce. Also comfort foods such as [[Nutella]], peanut butter and margarine. Plus, certain foods which contain ingredients which are rich in fiber.<ref>[http://www.space.com/22360-mars-food-mock-space-mission-hawaii.html "Mars Food Scientists End 4-Month Mock Space Mission In Hawaii"; by Mike Wall, SPACE.com Senior Writer]</ref>
==Astronaut applicant== In November 2011, NASA announced 15 available positions for its team of astronauts. Sierra-Sastre sent her application in January 2012. Her participation in the Mars project puts her one step closer to achieving her dream of becoming the first female Puerto Rican astronaut.<ref name="HSN"/>
Sierra-Sastre lives in [[Ithaca, New York]]. She is a freelance educator working with disadvantaged school districts and communities in Puerto Rico. Sierra-Sastre is also a research scientist and program manager at the [[Bureau of Engraving and Printing|U.S. Bureau of Engraving and Printing]]'s (BEP's) Office of Technology Development.<ref name=":0" /> ==The smallest U.S. National Anthem ever written== Sierra-Sastre also collaborates in a variety of projects with the National Nanotechnology Infrastructure Network and the Cornell Nanoscale Facility, which included writing the smallest [[The Star-Spangled Banner|US National Anthem]] ever written, ''[[La Borinqueña|La Borinqueña Más Pequeña]]'' (the Puerto Rican national anthem).<ref name="MCN"/><ref>[http://cienciapr.org/podcasts.php DCiencias PR] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120428045616/http://cienciapr.org/podcasts.php |date=April 28, 2012 }}</ref> Among the scientific works which she has co-authored is the 2008 article<ref name="Picraux Research Group">{{cite web|url=http://cint.lanl.gov/picraux_research.shtml |title=Picraux Research Group |publisher=Cint.lanl.gov |date= |accessdate=2013-09-20}}</ref> ''"Vertical Growth of [[Germanium|Ge]] Nanowires from Biotemplated [[Gold|Au]] Nanoparticle Catalysts,"'' published in the [[Journal of the American Chemical Society]], volume 130, issue 10488.<ref name="Picraux Research Group"/>
